author: Dan Martin
title: Barclays Center wants Islanders gone
text:
The Islanders’ constantly rocky relationship with Brooklyn could soon be coming to an end now that Barclays Center has decided it doesn’t want them around anymore.
According to two sources, the arena wants the Islanders out after 2018-19 because it believes it could make more revenue hosting mostly concerts and other events.
Nothing is official, however, and this could be part of a renegotiation of the deal between the two sides, but The Post first reported last year that both sides were looking to get out of the lease.
On Monday, Bloomberg News reported that the owner of both Barclays and the Nets, Russian billionaire Mikhail Prokhorov, shared a financial projection with prospective investors that showed the Islanders won’t contribute any revenue after the 2018-19 season, meaning the team’s days in Brooklyn are likely numbered.
“It was a marriage of convenience, but when the convenience is over, you usually get a divorce,” said a top government official briefed on the matter. “The arena was never built for hockey, so it was always destined to be a failure. I think most people involved [in the deal] didn’t truly believe they would be there long.”
At this point, the Islanders are most interested in returning to Long Island. The Post has previously reported the team’s new owners, Jonathan Ledecky and Scott Malkin, considered Belmont Park and Queens to be potential options. SEE ALSO

Islanders, Barclays eye escape clause to get team out of Brooklyn Governor Andrew Cuomo favors an arena at Belmont Park, a source close to the situation said, which is why the state in recent months rejected all proposals for the undeveloped site, including from those wanting to build retail stores, as well as the Cosmos ownership who wanted to build a soccer stadium.
The Dolans, who own the Knicks and MSG, would be involved in supporting the project, the source said, perhaps helping to book non-sports entertainment.
Last week, Queens Borough President Melinda Katz said she’d like to see the Willets Point site used for a hockey arena or soccer stadium, but never mentioned the Islanders by name.
Fans have been unhappy with the move since the beginning, as the team left its Nassau County fan base for a building not designed for hockey.
Average attendance this season is just 12,828, third-lowest in the league and there are a considerable amount of obstructed-view seats. To make matters worse, the ice surface has been consistently criticized — including by the Islanders’ own players — in part because the ice system is made of plastic pipes. SEE ALSO

Would one person support this Isles' arena pipe dream? “The owners are committed to the franchise, they’re committed to New York and the great fan base that has followed the Islanders,” NHL commissioner Gary Bettman said at the All-Star Game in Los Angeles over the weekend. “There are some issues about playing at Barclays. It may be fundamental to the ice system. That’s not something that can be fixed in the short term.’’
The Islanders played at Nassau Coliseum for over four decades before moving out of the antiquated building.
Charles Wang, who owned the Isles at the time, signed a 25-year lease with Barclays Center in 2012 that includes an out clause that can be triggered after the fourth season.
And although the Coliseum is scheduled to reopen in April after a $130 million renovation, it’s projected to have about 13,000 seats for hockey, making it too small to permanently house an NHL team.
Under the current lease, the Islanders gave up control of the business side of operations because they were running at a deficit. Barclays Center agreed to pay the Islanders an average lump sum of $53.5 million annually with the arena making its money off ticket and suite sales, sponsorships and other promotions, sources said.
A Barclays spokesman declined comment
— Additional reporting by Josh Kosman
